history.content:
As a 2-time CS70 TA, I'd say that the "maturity" required for CS70 does not need to come from certain classes, though classes like Math54, 16AB do help. Personally, the "maturity" means more of a way of thinking than any specific knowledge. It's almost never enough just to understand the theorems and results stated in the notes. You need to know how to use them, how to apply them in one context or another, and that's where the "maturity" comes from.

As for Stats classes, I'd say that basic knowledges about probability does help with some part of CS70, though the probability part of CS70 isn't really easy (esp. the last few lectures). Knowing something about probability will make your life easier for some time, but I'm not sure about the extent of such help.

children.subject: CS 70 is half probability, and being good at probability questions isn't quite the same thing as mathematical maturity. Mathematical maturity is probably more useful for upper div math, and EE127/CS 189 etc.

history.content:
I wanted to take CS70 during the fall, but now I am beginning to reconsider it. I took 54 this semester (I am still waiting on my grade for that), and 1B last semester so I don't really know whether I have the mathematical maturity to take such a proofs-based course.

Should I take EE16A in the fall instead? If I do that, I would then take 16B and 61C during the spring and CS 70 would then be pushed to summer 2018. I know that delays my major declaration, but I am not planning to do upper divs until junior year anyway. 

Would that be a good way to go (since Professor Sahai and a lot of other posters have stated numerous times that "soph. mathematical maturity" is built through the 16a/16b sequence)? 

For additional reference, I took CS 61A this semester and will be taking CS 61BL over the summer. I am also taking Stats 21 during the summer (potentially double-majoring in Econ)
history.subject: Mathematical Maturity for CS 70

history.content:
I wanted to take CS70 during the fall, but now I am beginning to reconsider it. I took 54 this semester (and did pretty horribly), and 1B last semester so I don't really know whether I have the mathematical maturity to take such a proofs-based course.

Should I take EE16A in the fall instead? Could that help with garnering the requisite skills to tackle CS 70 effectively? Or should I just jump in and do the other lower division pre-reqs later?

For reference, I took CS 61A this semester and will be taking CS 61BL over the summer.

EDIT: Oh, and another thing, since I am double-majoring in Econ, I am also taking Stats 21 this summer. Would that make a difference in terms of my general skill-level for CS 70?
